newsitem.title: UK: Indium shines in minor metals, cobalt slips.
newsitem.headline: Indium shines in minor metals, cobalt slips.

text.p: Indium featured in the industrial minor metals over the past week as consumers tried to cover their commitments in a market suffering from a lack of available metal.
Elsewhere, cobalt remained under downside pressure, while vanadium firmed.
The minor metal market, in line with other commodity markets, failed to react significantly to the death of China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping.
"We had a phone call from our Beijing office saying business as normal," one trader said.
China is a major player in all metals and other commodities.
Traders said indium drove higher as Chinese producers refused to sell into a market which has recently seen brisk Japanese based buying.
"They (the Chinese) have withdrawn from the market after the New Year holiday and are not showing signs of being sellers," one trader commented.
Traders said the Chinese producers were oversold and were not keen to sell spot material. They said China may not return in any force until March/April.
Tightness was not eased by Western producers who were also oversold or fully committed to Japanese contracts.

"There seems to be no material on the ground," a trader said. Peru was locked into long term contracts and had little readily available material, while Russia was offering small amounts of material at high prices.
Several traders suggested the market had the potential to rally over the coming weeks. They said levels of $300 per kilo or above was achievable.
Cobalt slipped back, despite the continuing warfare in Zaire. There was further talk of Russian offers.
Traders said they will closely eye the Defence National Stockpile which will open its negotiated bid for cobalt on February 20.
In the vanadium market prices US demand lifted prices. Traders said stocks were thin on the ground.
Mercury held steady but traders noted some Russian offers creeping into the market.
Recently, trade sources said that Russia may be prepared to release some material from strategic metal stockpiles.
They said that 420 tonnes of cobalt, 30,000 76 lbs flasks of mercury, 7,000 tonnes of titanium sponge and an undisclosed amount of chrome could be released.
Gallium was also underpinned by low stock levels from CIS producers. Japanese demand was also noted in gallium.
Magnesium was showing signs of easing on the back of over production.
Antimony under light Chinese selling drifted lower.
One trader said that Chinese stock had recently arrived at Rotterdam and that there was more on the way.
"There is selling in the market, though it is not aggressive," one trader said.
He believed the market had the potential to fall by around another $100.
